But I should check all rows to make sure there isn't a larger margin elsewhere.

Row 2: Dec 4 vs Pistons. 99-104. Celtics lost, so no.

Row 6: Dec 11 vs Nets. 130-121. 9 points.
Row 7: Dec 12 vs 76ers. 107-110. Loss.
Row 8: Dec 14 vs Jazz. 117-106. 11-point win.
Row 9: Dec 15 vs Hawks. 101-94. 7 points.

Row 11: Dec 22 vs Bulls. 85-110. Loss.
Row 12: Dec 26 vs Suns. 119-114. 5 points.
Row 13: Dec 27 vs Clippers. 118-103. 15 points.
Row 14: Dec 29 vs Spurs. 120-112. 8 points.
Row 15: Dec 30 vs Bucks. 98-114. Loss.

So, the only game where the Celtics had a win margin of 23 points or more is row 1 (Dec 2) with a 23-point win against the Cavaliers. That directly supports the claim.

Now, I need to check if there are any other games in December that might have a larger margin. From the table, none of the other Celtics' wins come close to 23 points. Their highest is the Dec 1 game with a 6-point win, then Dec 2 with 23, and others are smaller.

I should also check if there are any other rows where the Celtics have a larger margin, but from what I see, row 1 is the only one with a 23-point win. So, the claim is supported by this row.

Therefore, the relevant cell is row_index 1 and column_name "score". Because that's where the 23-point victory happened.
</think>

To verify the claim that the Boston Celtics had their largest win margin of 23 points in December, we examine each game in December. The game on December 2 against the Cavaliers resulted in a 122-99 score, indicating a 23-point win for the Celtics. This directly supports the claim.
